Oh!  ye unbending Glaciers! — if ye be</br>Aught more than human view may contemplate—</br>If on your crowned heads the Deity</br>Rests his bright foot eternal, when in state</br>He bends arrayed in lightnings — consecrate</br>Then stand for ever. — Perchance your heavenward look</br>Infused such feeling, strong and elevate,</br>That madness in the soul's bright temple shook—</br>Silent ye pointed high — I read as from a book.

Sacred ye are — The very eye of God</br>Darts roses on ye as it shuts at even—</br>The earthquake on your breast hath never trod—</br>Nor in vast fragments have your limbs been riven—</br>Nor through your heart the red volcano driven,</br>That foams in lava-cataracts from its bound;</br>Or flings its blazing columns up to heaven,—</br>Sinking in darkening ashes on the ground—</br>Thus Hecla — Etna feel — and all (save ye) around.

And oh!  thou viewless Spirit, who dost breath</br>Life on the world — whose home is on the seas,</br>And plains, and mountain summits — and beneath</br>This earth — whose couriers are the storm and breeze—</br>Whose children — the gay birds — the beasts — the trees—</br>And we (the monarchs of mortality)</br>And whatsoe'er hath being — That thou didst please</br>To draw from me the mind's calamity,</br>I thank thee — Thou hast given the world again to me.

For not alone with Alpine heights my soul</br>Communed in silence — 'Twas from forests deep—</br>The everlasting ocean, that doth roll</br>Bursting in thundering billows 'gainst the steep—</br>The rainbow, that when summer vapours weep,</br>Arches the sky — the free and sightless wind—</br>The Moon — the Sun — and (last) those firest that keep</br>Nightly their starry watch — From all, my mind</br>Caught light, and strength, and joy — to no one aid confined—</br>
